noteParagraph.text: Definitions for Section C:
Alkali metals: Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr
Alkaline earth metals: Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra
Lanthanides: elements with atomic numbers 57 to 71 inclusive
Rare earths: Sc, Y, Lanthanides
Actinides: elements with atomic numbers 89 to 103 inclusive
Refractory metals: Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W
Halogens: F, Cl, Br, I, At
Noble gases: He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn
Platinum group: Os, Ir, Pt, Ru, Rh, Pd
Noble metals: Ag, Au, Platinum group
Light metals: alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, Be, Al, Mg
Heavy metals: metals other than light metals
Iron group: Fe, Co, Ni
Non-metals: H, B, C, Si, N, P, O, S, Se, Te, noble gases, halogens
Metals: elements other than non-metals
Transition elements: elements with atomic numbers 21 to 30 inclusive, 39 to 48 inclusive, 57 to 80 inclusive, 89 upwards

titlePart.entryReference: by using ultra-high pressure, e.g. for the formation of diamonds

titlePart.text: UNIDIRECTIONAL SOLIDIFICATION OF EUTECTIC MATERIALS OR UNIDIRECTIONAL DEMIXING OF EUTECTOID MATERIALS

titlePart.entryReference: for producing semi-conductor devices or parts thereof

titlePart.text: DOPING PROCESSES FOR CRYSTALS IN GENERAL
titlePart.entryReference: for producing semi-conductor devices or parts thereof

titlePart.text: REFINING BY ZONE-MELTING OF MATERIALS IN GENERAL

noteParagraph.text: In this sub-class, the term "single crystal" includes also twin crystals and a predominantly single crystal product.
Inventions dealing with the preparation of single crystals of particular materials or shapes are classified in the group for the process as well as in group .
Apparatus specially adapted for a specific process is classified in the appropriate group for the process. Apparatus to be used in more than one kind of process is classified in group .

titlePart.text: Single-crystal growth directly from the solid state
by thermal treatment, e.g. strain annealing
by solid state reactions or multi-phase diffusion
by pressure treatment during the growth
with addition of doping material Single-crystal growth from liquids
Single-crystal growth from solutions using solvents which are liquid at normal temperature, e.g. aqueous solutions
by application of pressure, e.g. hydrothermal processes
the crystallising material being formed by chemical reactions in the solution
Single-crystal growth from melt solutions using molten solvents
by evaporation of the molten solvent
using as solvent a component of the crystal composition
Single-crystal-growth by normal freezing or freezing under temperature gradient, e.g. Bridgman-Stockbarger method
adding crystallising material or reactants forming it in situ to the melt
at least one but not all components of the crystal composition being added
every component of the crystal composition being added during the crystallisation
Solid or liquid components, e.g. Verneuil method
characterised by the seed, e.g. its crystallographic orientation

titlePart.entryReference: by changing the cross-section of the treated solid
zone-refining of specific materials, see the relevant sub-classes for the materials

titlePart.text: Zone-melting with a solvent, e.g. travelling solvent process
the molten zone not extending over the whole cross-section
adding crystallising material or reactants forming it in situ to the molten zone
in the gaseous or vapour state
the heating element being in contact with, or immersed in, the molten zone
by induction, e.g. hot wire technique
Stabilisation or shape controlling of the molten zone, e.g. by concentrators, by electromagnetic fields
Controlling the section of the crystal
Mechanisms for moving either the charge or the heater
characterised by the seed, e.g. by its crystallographic orientation
Single-crystal growth by pulling from a melt, e.g. Czochralski method
adding crystallising material or reactants forming it in situ to the melt
adding doping material, e.g. for np-junction
Crucibles or containers for supporting the melt
Heating of the melt or the crystallised material
using direct resistance heating in addition to other methods of heating, e.g. using Peltier heat
Stabilisation or shape controlling of the molten zone near the pulled crystal
Controlling the section of the crystal
using mechanical means, e.g. shaping guides
titlePart.entryReference: shaping dies for edge-defined film-fed crystal growth

titlePart.text: using weight changes of the crystal or the melt, e.g. flotation methods
Mechanisms for rotating or moving either the melt or the crystal
Edge-defined film-fed crystal growth using dies or slits
characterised by the seed, e.g. its crystallographic orientation
Single-crystal growth on to a seed which remains in the melt during growth, e.g. Nacken-Kyropoulos method
the solvent being a component of the crystal composition
Heating of the reaction chamber or the substrate
by normal casting or gradient freezing
by pulling from a melt Single-crystal growth from vapours
Single-crystal growth by condensing evaporated or sublimed material
Pattern deposit, e.g. by using masks
Heating of the deposition chamber, the substrate, or the material to be evaporated
Single-crystal growth by chemical reaction of reactive gases, e.g. chemical vapour-deposition growth
Pattern deposit, e.g. by using masks
Heating of the reaction chamber or the substrate
Feed and outlet means for the gases
Modifying the flow of the reactive gases
the substrate being of the same material as the epitaxial layer
Single-crystal growth under a protective fluid
Single crystals characterised by the material or by their shape

noteParagraph.text: In groups , in the absence of an indication to the contrary, a material is classified in the last appropriate place.

titlePart.text: with formula AMeO3 , wherein A is a rare earth metal and Me is Fe, Ga, Sc, Cr, Co, or Al, e.g. ortho ferrites
with formula BMe2O4 , wherein B is Mg, Ni, Co, Al, Zn or Cd and Me is Fe, Ga, Sc, Cr, Co, or Al
with formula A3Me5O12 , wherein A is a rare earth metal and Me is Fe, Ga, Sc, Cr, Co or Al, e.g. garnets
Whiskers or needles After-treatment of single crystals
Diffusion or doping processes for single crystals
by contacting with diffusion material in the solid state
by contacting with diffusion material in the liquid state
by contacting with diffusion material in the gaseous state
the diffusion material being a compound of the elements to be diffused
Feed and outlet means for the gases
Modifying the flow of the gases
Doping by irradiation with electromagnetic waves or by particle radiation

titlePart.entryReference: mechanical fine working of gems, jewels, crystals

titlePart.text: Apparatus in general, specially adapted for single-crystal-growth, diffusion, or doping processes
